banner.title: TP WorkLife 10/12
banner.mainContentHeadline: The podcast where science meets business
banner.mainContent: From fixing meetings to finding a mentor, get new insights to help you enjoy your time at work and thrive in your career.

videoData.title: Mysteries of vernacular: Sarcophagus
videoData.description: Dating back to the early Roman Empire, the word sarcophagus originally referred to the limestone a coffin was made of, rather than the coffin itself. From flesh-eating stone to a stone coffin, Jessica Oreck and Rachael Teel unbury the sarcophagus. [Directed by Jessica Oreck, narrated by Graham James, music by Nate Shaw and Eli Janney].
videoData.socialDescription: Dating back to the early Roman Empire, the word sarcophagus originally referred to the limestone a coffin was made of, rather than the coffin itself. From flesh-eating stone to a stone coffin, Jessica Oreck and Rachael Teel unbury the sarcophagus. [Directed by Jessica Oreck, narrated by Graham James, music by Nate Shaw and Eli Janney].

cues.text: The history of the word sarcophagus
it seems to come right out

Rather than having
a B-movie origin, however,

its roots can be traced back
to the early Roman Empire
was used to describe the limestone
that a coffin was made of,

According to the Roman
scholar Pliny the Elder,
that limestone from a quarry near Troy
For this reason, it was quite desireable

Though it's unclear
if the belief was widespread
or even accurately reported by Pliny,
what is certain is that sarkophagus
came from the Greek words sark,

for the final resting
place of the deceased.
